name: Laccha Paratha
history: Laccha Paratha is an Indian flatbread that gained popularity in North India. Its name 'Laccha' means 'layers', reflecting the unique layered texture of this bread, which is a result of its distinctive folding and rolling technique.
description: Laccha Paratha is a flaky, layered flatbread made from whole wheat flour. It is known for its crispy, multi-layered texture, achieved through a series of pleats and rolls before cooking on a griddle. It's often served with rich curries and gravies.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: Mix whole wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water and knead into a soft dough. Let it rest for 15 minutes.

instructions.title: Roll and Layer the Parathas
instructions.description: Divide the dough into equal portions. Roll each portion into a large circle, apply ghee or oil, and fold into pleats. Roll up the pleated dough into a spiral, then flatten and roll out into a circle again.

instructions.title: Cook the Parathas
instructions.description: Heat a griddle and cook each paratha with ghee or oil until golden brown spots appear on both sides.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the hot laccha parathas with curry, dal, or yogurt.

tips: The key to perfect layers is in the rolling and pleating technique.
Cook on medium heat for even cooking and crispiness.
variations: Add spices like cumin or carom seeds for a flavorful twist.
Stuff with vegetables or paneer for a stuffed version.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh but can be stored in an airtight container for up to 24 hours.
storage.instructions: Reheat on a griddle before serving if stored.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on a hot griddle or tawa until warm and soft.
presentationTips: Serve stacked on a platter, showcasing the layers.
Accompany with a variety of dips and side dishes for a complete meal.
